39. The language of SZ. As regards the awkward and “inelegant” language of this book, we may say this much: It is one thing to simply tell a story about things and quite another to understand the being of things,. That is a task for which we currently lack both the vocabulary and the “grammar.”
When we compare the ontological sections of Plato's Parmenides or Aristotle's Metaphysics VII with the narrative sections of Thucydides' History of the Peloponnesian War, we cannot help but be struck by how strange was the philosophical jargon that Plato and Aristotle inflicted on the Greek language. Today, the problems of ontology have become much harder than they were for the Greeks even as our philosophical powers have become weaker. Therefore, it is virtually inevitable that the concepts in this text will be complex and that the way we express them will be equally rough.
